title: 1D kinematics - x equals -t squared plus Bt plus C

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. The graph represents the position <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> of a particle that moves along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. At <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> the particle is at position <math alttext="x equals negative 3 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math>. At both times <math alttext="t equals 1 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math> and <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math> the particle is at position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. (a) Using features of the graph, justify whether the particle’s velocity and acceleration are either positive, negative, or zero at times <math alttext="t equals 1 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math> and <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>s</mtext></math>. Your justification should use qualitative reasoning beyond referencing equations.

(b) The motion of the particle is described by the equation <math alttext="x of t equals, negative t squared plus B t, plus C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>t</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>C</mi></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math> and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math> are constants (not necessarily positive). Derive equations for both the velocity <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> and the acceleration <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> of the particle as functions of time. Express <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> and <math alttext="a" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> in terms of <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>B</mi></math>, <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math>, and <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math>, as appropriate.

(c) To describe the motion of a second particle moving along the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis, a term <math alttext="D times, open parenthesis, t minus 2, close parenthesis" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> is a positive constant, is added to the equation given in part (b) for the first particle. Describe how a graph of <math alttext="x of t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></math> for this second particle is different from the graph given for the first particle in terms of when the second particle’s position is zero, and justify your answer.
